questions.text: If a tumor compresses the structures passing through the opening marked in the given image, which of the following sensations would be affected?

options.label: C
options.text: Sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose

questions.correct_answer: C. Sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sensation in the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose The marked foramen is superior orbital fissure. The branches of Ophthalmic nerve traverses through Superior orbital fissure. The ophthalmic nerve (V1) of the trigeminal nerve provides sensory innervation to the anterior scalp and dorsum of the nose. Structure passing through Superior orbital Fissure

Highyeild:

The supraorbital nerve, a branch of the frontal nerve, supplies the skin of the anterior scalp, forehead, and middle of the upper eyelids The external nasal nerve, a branch of the anterior ethmoidal nerve, supplies the skin of the dorsum of the nose. The ophthalmic nerve provides sensory innervation to the roof of the nasal cavity.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Sensation of the nasopharynx The nasopharynx is a passageway in the throat that allows air to pass from the nose to the lungs. The sensation of the nasopharynx is primarily derived from the following nerves: Glossopharyngeal (IX) : Provides sensory fibers to the upper pharynx Vagus (X) : Contributes to the general sensory perception of the pharynx Maxillary (V2) : Supplies sensory innervation to the anterior portion of the roof and floor of the nasopharynx. Option: B. Mucosa of the nasal cavity The nasal mucosa detects sensations in the nose through a complex system of nerves and sensory structures: Olfactory Nerve Responsible for the sense of smell, the olfactory nerve is one of the main interpreters of chemosensory information. The olfactory mucosa, a specialized part of the nasal mucosa, contains receptors for smell. Trigeminal Nerve The ophthalmic and maxillary divisions of the trigeminal nerve provide sensory innervation to the nasal mucosa. When activated, these nerves can cause sensations of pain or irritation, which can lead to sneezing. Option: D. Sensation of the chin The mental nerve will provide sensory innervation to the anterior territory of the buccal mucosa, lower lip, and the skin of the chin ventral to its foramen.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A chronic tobacco consumer went to the dental clinic with bleeding lesions on his tongue and was diagnosed with carcinoma of the tongue. Which of the following papillae, which do not have taste buds, is least likely to be involved in such a cancer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Filiform Filiform papillae do not have taste buds. They are non-taste papillae that make up the majority of the tongue's papillae and give the tongue its texture and sense of touch. Filiform papillae cover most of the tongue's front two-thirds.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Circumvallate Circumvallate papillae, also known as vallate papillae, are V-shaped bumps on the back of the tongue that contain taste buds. Circumvallate papillae contain about 50% of the taste buds on the tongue. Option: C. Fungiform Fungiform papillae are found only on the anterior two-thirds of the tongue; the highest density (about 30/cm 2 ) is at the tip. They have a mushroom-like structure and typically have about 3 taste buds at their apical surface. Option: D. Foliate Foliate papillae are less numerous and are found at the dorsolateral corners of the tongue, where they define the edges of a series of grooves. Many taste buds are found on these papillae.

questions.text: What is the outer covering of the condition shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Amnion Exomphalos or omphalocele: This anomaly results from failure of coils of the small intestine to return into the abdominal cavity from their physiological herniation into extraembryonic celom during the sixth to tenth week of IUL. It occurs in 2.5/10,000 births and could be associated with cardiac and neural tube defects.

Highyeild:

Clinically, it presents as a rounded mass protruding from the umbilicus as shown in the image. This mass contains coils of the small intestine and is covered by a transparent amniotic membrane.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Chorion Option: C. Endoderm Option: D. Ectoderm An omphalocele (also known as exomphalos) is a midline abdominal wall defect of variable size with the herniated viscera covered by a membrane consisting of peritoneum on the inner surface, amnion on the outer surface, and Wharton's jelly between the layers, therefore Option A, C and D are incorrect answers.

questions.text: An absent gag reflex can result from injury to which of the following nerves?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IX and X The gag reflex, also known as the pharyngeal reflex, is an involuntary reflex that protects the throat from foreign objects: The afferent and efferent nerves involved in the gag reflex are: Afferent nerve - The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) carries sensory information to the nucleus solitarius in the medulla oblongata. This nerve supplies sensory innervation to the oropharynx. Efferent nerve- The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) carries motor information from the nucleus ambiguus in the medulla oblongata to the pharyngeal muscles.

Highyeild:

The gag reflex is a muscular contraction of the back of the throat that occurs when the back of the tongue, tonsils, uvula, or roof of the mouth are touched. The glossopharyngeal nerve sends stimuli to the nucleus solitarius and spinal trigeminal nucleus, which then signals the vagus nerve to contract the muscles in the pharynx. The gag reflex is an evolutionary reflex that prevents choking and swallowing foreign objects.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: B. VII and X: The afferent and efferent nerves of gag reflex is IX and X cranial nerves. Option: C. VII and v: The afferent and efferent nerves of gag reflex is IX and X cranial nerves. Option: D. V and IX: The afferent and efferent nerves of gag reflex is IX and X cranial nerves .

questions.text: Which artery is used for arteriovenous shunting with the great saphenous vein for hemodialysis, and is located behind the medial malleolus and 2.5 cm in front of the tendo calcaneus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Posterior tibial artery The posterior tibial artery is located behind the medial malleolus and midway between the medial malleolus and the medial border of the tendo calcaneus.

Highyeild:

The posterior tibial artery can be palpated by curling your fingers around the ankle and indenting the soft tissues between the medial malleolus and the Achilles tendon.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Anterior tibial artery The artery is most easily palpable as it begins to cross the anterior ankle joint. Ask your subject to actively dorsiflex their foot at the ankle in order to identify the tibialis anterior and extensor digitorum longus tendons. Option: C. Peroneal artery The peroneal artery (also termed the fibular artery) is the posterior lateral branch of the tibial-peroneal trunk in the lower extremity just distal to the popliteal fossa. Option: D. Circumflex fibular artery The circumflex fibular branch of the posterior tibial artery extends through the soleus muscle and winds laterally around the head of the fibula, passing deep to the common fibular nerve.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Where will you find the epithelium shown in the image?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ureter The above image is of ureter The ureter is a muscular tube that carries urine from the kidney to the bladder, and its epithelium is made up of transitional epithelium. Transitional epithelium is a type of epithelium that has three layers: Superficial layer: Contains umbrella cells Intermediate layer: Contains cuboidal and low columnar cells Basal layer: A single layer of cells.

Highyeild:

The ureters, bladder, and the initial portion of the urethra are all lined with transitional epithelium, which is also called urothelium. This specialized epithelium is only found in the urinary system and it allows the conducting passageways and bladder to expand a lot while staying impermeable to water and ions.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Gallbladder The epithelial lining of the gall bladder consists of simple columnar cells specialized for absorption, with an apical brush border of microvilli, very similar to intestinal absorptive cells. Option: B. Trachea The trachea's epithelium is ciliated pseudostratified columnar epithelium. This specialized tissue protects the lungs from inhaled particles and microorganisms. Option: D. Duodenum The duodenum is similar to all the other hollow organs of the gastrointestinal tract: mucosa, submucosa and muscularis. The mucosa consists of simple columnar epithelium (lamina epithelialis), a connective tissue layer (lamina propria) and a smooth muscle layer (lamina muscularis).

questions.text: During the examination of a patient, a professor asks the patient to invert his foot and points to a prominent tendon located behind the medial malleolus. Which tendon is being highlighted?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tibialis Posterior The tendon of the tibialis posterior muscle descends posterior to the medial malleolus.

Highyeild:

The tibialis posterior muscle originates on the inner posterior border of the fibula laterally. It is also attached to the interosseous membrane medially, which attaches to the tibia and fibula. It terminates by dividing into plantar, main, and recurrent components. The main portion inserts into the tuberosity of the navicular bone . The smaller portion inserts into the plantar surface of the medial cuneiform. The plantar portion inserts into the bases of the second, third and fourth metatarsals, the intermediate and lateral cuneiforms and the cuboid. The recurrent portion inserts into the sustentaculum tali of the calcaneus.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Tibialis anterior The tibialis anterior muscle arises from the upper 2/3 of the lateral surface of the tibia and the adjoining part of the interosseous membrane and deep fascia overlying it, and the intermuscular septum between this muscle and the extensor digitorum longus. It is inserted into the medial and inferior surface of the medial cuneiform bone, and adjacent portion of the first metatarsal bone. Option: B. Extensor digitorum Most EDL arises from the anterior surface of the fibula, the upper part of the anterior surface of the interosseous membrane, and the lateral tibial condyle. The tendon of EDL passes under the superior and inferior extensor retinaculum at the anterior surface of the ankle joint before reaching its distal insertion. It divides into four slips that insert into the proximal and distal phalanges of the lateral four digits of the foot - digits 2-5. Option: D. Extensor hallucis longus EHL arises from the middle two quarters of the anterior surface of fibula and the adjacent interosseous membrane. EHL passes deep to the extensor retinaculum before inserting at the base of the distal phalanx of the big toe.

questions.text: An elderly woman reports difficulty in buttoning her shirt and increased clumsiness during daily activities. On examination, she is unable to make an 'O' shape by opposing her thumb and index finger. Which of the following muscles is most likely involved?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Abductor pollicis brevis The above condition is caused by anterior interosseous nerve injury. The OK sign test is a clinical test to evaluate for potential injury of the anterior interosseous nerve , Therefore the nerve affected can be the median nerve as it gives an anterior interosseous nerve as a branch. Among the options given above , Abductor pollicis brevis is the best answer because it is supplied by only the median nerve.

Highyeild:

The patient is typically asked to oppose their thumb with the second digit. With an anterior interosseous nerve injury, opposition of the thumb and second digit can still be possible. However, paresis of the flexor digitorum profundus (lateral part) and flexor pollicis longus muscles can lead to the absence of flexion of the second digit distal interphalangeal joint and at the thumb interphalangeal joint. Hand posture in anterior interosseous syndrome due to paresis of flexor digitorum Profundis and flexor pollicis longus mm.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Opponens pollicis The opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis (FPB) muscles are usually innervated by the median nerve, but the ulnar nerve can occasionally innervate the opponens pollicis. Option: B. Palmar interossei The deep branch of the ulnar nerve supplies the palmar interossei muscles in the hand. Option: C. Flexor pollicis brevis The opponens pollicis and flexor pollicis brevis (FPB) muscles are usually innervated by the median nerve, but the ulnar nerve can occasionally innervate the FPB.

Solution:

Medial pectoral nerve The above nerve marked in image is medial pectoral nerve because, The medial pectoral nerve originates from the medial cord of the brachial plexus, and is made up of fibers from the eighth cervical and first thoracic nerve roots.

Highyeild:

The medial pectoral nerve runs along the lower border of the pectoralis minor muscle, and then penetrates the muscle. It then emerges anteriorly and pierces the lower half of the pectoralis major muscle.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Thoracodorsal Nerve The TDN runs under the axillary vein, along the posterior wall of the axilla, and then along the posterolateral chest wall. It joins the vascular pedicle of the latissimus dorsi muscle. Option: C. Subscapular Nerve The subscapular nerves are a group of nerves that originate from the brachial plexus' posterior cord and innervate the muscles that move the scapula. There are multiple subscapular nerves, including the upper subscapular nerve, the lower subscapular nerve. Option: D. Long thoracic nerve The LTN originates from the C5–C7 cervical spinal nerves, and runs along the chest wall, deep to the clavicle, and superficial to the first and second ribs. It divides into smaller branches that run parallel to the main trunk, and then turn at right angles to innervate the serratus anterior muscle.

questions.text: A patient presents with sciatica and tenderness in the hamstring muscles. Which nerve supplies the hybrid muscle that is likely to be spared in this condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Obturator Nerve The adductor portion of the adductor magnus is innervated by the posterior division of the obturator nerve (L2-L4). The adductor magnus hamstring portion is so named due to its similarity in structure, proximal attachment, and innervation to the hamstring muscles.

Highyeild:

The adductor magnus muscle is innervated by two nerves: Obturator nerve- The posterior division of the obturator nerve supplies the adductor portion of the muscle. The obturator nerve originates from the L2 to L4 nerve roots of the lumbar plexus. Tibial division of the sciatic nerve- The tibial division of the sciatic nerve supplies the hamstring portion of the muscle.

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Common peroneal nerve The common peroneal nerve innervates the short head of the biceps femoris muscle. Option: B. Tibial nerve The tibial nerve innervates the semimembranosus, semitendinosus, and long head of the biceps femoris muscles. The common peroneal branch of the sciatic nerve innervates the short head of the biceps femoris. Option: C. Femoral nerve The femoral nerve innervates the following muscles: Quadriceps femoris : This group of muscles, which includes the rectus femoris, vastus lateralis, vastus medialis, and vastus intermedius, extends the leg at the knee joint. The rectus femoris also helps to steady the hip joint and flex the thigh. Iliacus : This hip flexor muscle is innervated by the femoral nerve. Pectineus : This muscle is innervated by the femoral nerve. Sartorius : This knee extensor muscle is innervated by the femoral nerve.

Table:

#MANTRA Lower limb muscles with dual nerve supply Muscle Nerves Adductor magnus Adductor part - posterior division of obturator nerve Hamstring part -tibial part of sciatic nerve. Biceps femoris Long head - tibial part of sciatic nerve Short head - common peroneal nerve. Pectineus Anterior part - femoral nerve Medial part - obturator nerve Iliopsoas Iliacus - Femoral nerve Psoas - Anterior rami of L1,2,3 spinal nerves
